CSCI*100.Description: (3) This course incorporates critical thinking as students learn about the Internet and the World Wide Web. Topics include introductory computing concepts, networking basics, the Internet, utilizing Web technologies responsibly, social networking, privacy, and digital security. F,S,Su
CSCI*100.Title: Intro Internet/World Wide Web

CSCI*101.Description: (3 credits) This course incorporates critical thinking as students learn about the Internet and the World Wide Web. Topics include introductory computing concepts, networking basics, the Internet, utilizing Web technologies responsibly, social networking, privacy, and digital security. F,S,Su
CSCI*101.Title: Intro Internet/World Wide Web

CSCI*110.Description: (3 credits)(Prereq: Business or Computer Science major, or permission of instructor) A survey course designed for Business or Computer Science majors. The course focuses on business applications involving beginning and intermediate spreadsheets and presentation software. F,S,Su
CSCI*110.Title: Business Applications

CSCI*120.Description: (3 credits) An introduction to the design and development of interactive Web 2.0 user interfaces using client-side programming languages. Topics include layout and design for multiple screen sizes, form creation and validation, client-side DOM manipulation, coding frameworks, and interaction design best practices. F,S,Su.
CSCI*120.Title: Intro Web Interface Developmnt

CSCI*130.Description: (3 credits)(Computer Usage) Designed as an introduction to Computer Science; provides a comprehensive overview of the field of Computer Science in areas such as machine architecture, data storage, data manipulation, operating systems, algorithms, programming language, data structures, database structures, computational complexity, and artificial intelligence; includes a brief introduction to programming. Offered as needed
CSCI*130.Title: Intro to Computer Science

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Students must have completed MATH*130B or have been placed into MATH*135 or higher.
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

CSCI*135.Description: (3 credits)(Students are required to have a personal notebook computer for this course)(Prereq: A grade of 'C' or better in MATH*130B or placed into MATH*135 or higher) This course provides an introduction to computer programming using a dynamically typed language. Topics include algorithm development, input/output, conditional statements, loops, functions, and use of basic data structures. F,S
CSCI*135.Title: Introduction to Programming

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Student must have completed MATH 130, MATH*130B MATH 130I, MATH 131, MATH 132, MATH 135, MATH 160, MATH*160B, MATH*161 or MATH 161B with a grade of C or better or a placement test score of MATH 132, MATH 135, MATH 160. Coreq is CSCI 140L.
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Take CSCI*140L
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be taken either prior to or at the same time as this course.

CSCI*140.Description: (3 credits)(Computer Usage)(Prereq: MATH*130, MATH*130B, MATH*130i, MATH*131, MATH*132, MATH*135, MATH*160, MATH*160B, MATH*161, or MATH*161B; all with a grade of 'C' or better, or a placement score of MATH*132, MATH*135, MATH*160)(Coreq: CSCI*140L) An introduction to problem solving and algorithmic design methodology using a high-level programming language. Topics include problem solving techniques; subprograms and modularity; fundamental data types and structures; flow of control statements; and file input/output. Three lecture hours per week. Offered as needed
CSCI*140.FullTitleDisplay: CSCI*140 Intro to Algorithmic Design I
CSCI*140.Title: Intro to Algorithmic Design I

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Student must have completed MATH 130, MATH*130B, MATH 130I, MATH 131, MATH 132, MATH 135, MATH 160, MATH*160B, MATH*161 or MATH 161B with a grade of C or better or a placement test score of MATH 132, MATH 135, MATH 160.  Coreq is CSCI 140.
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Take CSCI*140
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be taken either prior to or at the same time as this course.

CSCI*140L.Description: (1 credit)(Prereq: MATH*130, MATH*130B, MATH*130i, MATH*131, MATH*132, MATH*135, MATH*160, MATH*160B, MATH*161, or MATH*161B; all with a grade of 'C' or better, or a placement test score of MATH*132, MATH*135, MATH*160)(Coreq: CSCI*140) Laboratory demonstrates the topics and principles presented in the lecture. Offered as needed
CSCI*140L.FullTitleDisplay: CSCI*140L Intro Algorithmic Design I Lab
CSCI*140L.Title: Intro Algorithmic Design I Lab

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Students must have completed CSCI 135 or CSCI 140 and CSCI 140L with a minimum grade of C.
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

CSCI*145.Description: (3 credits)(Students are required to have a personal notebook computer for this course)(Prereq: CSCI*135 with a grade of 'C' or better, or CSCI*140/L with a grade 'C' or better) This course continues the study of programming in a dynamically typed language. Topics include object-oriented development, user-defined data types, debugging, testing, and elementary distributed computing. F,S
CSCI*145.Title: Intermediate Programming

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Student must have completed CSCI 140 and CSCI 140L both with grade of C or better and the choice of MATH 130, MATH*130B, MATH 130I, MATH 131, MATH 132, MATH 135, MATH 160, MATH*160B, MATH*161 or MATH 161B; all with a grade of C or better.
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Take CSCI*150L
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be taken either prior to or at the same time as this course.

CSCI*150.Description: (3 credits)(Computer Usage)(Students are required to have a personal notebook computer for this course)(Prereq: CSCI*140/L and the choice of MATH*130, MATH*130B, MATH*130i, MATH*131, MATH*132, MATH*135, MATH*160, MATH*160B, MATH*161, or MATH*161B; all with a grade of 'C' or better)(Coreq: CSCI*150L) A contiuation of CSCI*140. Continued development of discipline in program design, style and expression, debugging and testing. Topics include object oriented programming and algorithm design; elementary data structures; user-defined data types, inheritance, and encapsulation. Offered as needed
CSCI*150.Title: Intro Algorithmic Design II

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Student must have completed CSCI 140/140L both with a grade of C or better and the choice of MATH 130, MATH*130B, MATH 130I, MATH 131, MATH 132, MATH 135, MATH 160, MATH*160B, MATH*161 or MATH*161B all with a minimum grade of C.
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Take CSCI*150
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be taken either prior to or at the same time as this course.

CSCI*150L.Description: (1 credit)(Prereq: CSCI*140/L and the choice of MATH*130, MATH*130B, MATH*130i, MATH*131, MATH*132, MATH*135, MATH*160, MATH*160B, MATH*161, or MATH*161B; all with a grade of 'C' or better)(Coreq: CSCI*150) Laboratory demonstrates the topics and principles presented in the lecture. Offered as needed
CSCI*150L.FullTitleDisplay: CSCI*150L Intro Algorithmic Design II Lb
CSCI*150L.Title: Intro Algorithmic Design II Lb

CSCI*170.Description: (1 credit) Provides real-world experiences that stimulate discussion of ethical issues in the technical work place. Topics include: ACM Code of Ethics, general moral responsibilities, privacy security, copyright and ownership agreements, computer crimes, and personal ethics. Class format presents case studies of current news events regarding computer ethics. Offered as needed
CSCI*170.Title: Ethics in Computer Science

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Students must have completed CSCI*145 with a grade of 'C' or better.
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

CSCI*204.Description: (3 credits)(Prereq: A grade of 'C' or better in CSCI*145) Students learn to program in the Javascript programming language. Topics include basic syntax and structures, the DOM (Document Object Model), event-driven architecture, asynchronous programming, APIs, client and server side programming, the HTTP, and frameworks. Offered as needed
CSCI*204.Title: Programming in Javascript

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Student must have received a grade of 'C' or better in CSCI*145 or CSCI*150/L.
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

CSCI*207.Description: (3 credits)(Prereq: A grade of 'C' or better in CSCI*145 or CSCI*150/L) Computer programming in the C++ language. Offered as needed
CSCI*207.Title: Programming in C++

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Students must have received a 'C' or better in CSCI*145 or CSCI*150/L.
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

CSCI*208.Description: (3 credits)(Prereq: A grade of 'C' or better in CSCI*145 or CSCI*150/L) An introduction to programming with Visual Basic including Windows interface controls, Active X controls, and database access using Active X objects. Offered as needed
CSCI*208.Title: Programming in Visual Basic

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Student must have completed CSCI*145 or CSCI*150/L with a  minimum grade of C.
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

CSCI*209.Description: (3 credits)(Prereq: A grade of 'C' or better in CSCI*145 or CSCI*150/L). Students learn to program in the Java programming language. Topics include inheritance, threads, graphics, network programming, and Web-programming. Offered as needed
CSCI*209.Title: Programming in Java

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Student must have completed CSCI*145 or CSCI*150/L, and MATH*174 all with a grade of C or better.
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

CSCI*210.Description: (3 credits)(Prereq: A grade of 'C' or better in CSCI*145 or CSCI*150/L, and MATH*174) Logical basis of computer structure, machine representation of information, flow of control, instruction codes, arithmetic and logical operations, indexing, indirect addressing, input-output, sub-routines, linkages, macros. Interpretive and assembly systems, and pushdown stacks. F
CSCI*210.Title: Computer Organization

CSCI*211.Description: (3 credits) This course covers core computer hardware, including the relationships between components of a computer system. Software components are also introduced, including the fundamentals of the computer operating system and an introduction to virtualization systems. F,S
CSCI*211.Title: Computer Infrastructure

CSCI*216.Description: (3 credits)This course provides students with a  fundamental understanding of how to use a Linux  operating system. Topics include accessing the  command file, file manipulation, managing users  and groups, file system permissions, controlling  services, managing processes, configuring  networking, and using package managers. F,S
CSCI*216.Title: Linux Fundamentals I

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Student must have completed CSCI*145 or CSCI*150/L, and MATH*174 all with a grade of 'C' or better.
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

CSCI*220.Description: (3 credits)(Prereq: A grade of 'C' or better in CSCI*145 or CSCI*150/L, and MATH*174) Topics include analysis of algorithms, with emphasis on computational complexity and advanced algorithms including self-adjusting trees, hashing, graphs, sorting, searching, and greedy algorithms. F,S
CSCI*220.LocationsDisplay: Coastal - Main:, Coastal Science Center, Burroughs & Chapin Mar Wet Ct
CSCI*220.Title: Data Structures

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Student must have taken MATH*174 and CSCI*135 or CSCI*140/L with a grade of 'C' or better.
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

CSCI*225.Description: (3 credits)(Prereq: A grade of 'C' or better in MATH*174 and CSCI*135 or CSCI*140/L) This course will provide an introduction to relational database concepts and the design of relational databases. It will also provide a thorough introduction to SQL. F,S
CSCI*225.Title: Intro Relational Database/SQL

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Complete CSCI*135 or CSCI*140/L, with a grade of C or better.
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

CSCI*250.Description: (3 credits)(Prereq: a grade of C or better in CSCI*135 or CSCI*140/L) This course covers the key aspects of information management including the acquisition, classification, storage, analysis, presentation, and archival of information. Privacy and security of information are also addressed. The course connects theoretical concepts with practice through experiential learning activities that are designed to provide students with real-world experiences related to the life cycle of information. F,S
CSCI*250.Title: Information Management

CSCI*270.Description: (3 credits) Fundamentals of data communications, including hardware, basic components of communications, configurations, networks and applications, protocols, security, and software are discussed. F,S
CSCI*270.FullTitleDisplay: CSCI*270 Data Comms Systems and Network
CSCI*270.Title: Data Comms Systems and Network

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Take CSCI 145 or CSCI*150/L with a C or better.
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Students must have completed CSCI*120, CSCI*225, and CSCI*270 with a grade of 'C' or better.
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

CSCI*303.Description: (3 credits)(Prereq: A grade of 'C' or better in CSCI*145 or CSCI*150/L; and CSCI*120, CSCI*225, and CSCI*270) A thorough introduction to development and deployment of web-based applications. Topics include middleware programming concepts, client server architecture, database access, state management, and application security. Students are expected to already have proficiency with introductory computer programming, HTML, CSS, Javascript, and SQL or other database query framework. F,S
CSCI*303.FullTitleDisplay: CSCI*303 Intro Server-Side Web App Devo
CSCI*303.Title: Intro Server-Side Web App Devo

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Student must have completed CSCI*145 or CSCI*150/L, and CSCI*210, and MATH*174 with a grade of 'C' or better.
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Students must have completed CSCI*145 or CSCI*150/L, and CSCI*210, and MATH*174 with a grade of 'C' or better.
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

CSCI*310.Description: (3 credits)(Prereq: A grade of 'C' or better in CSCI*145 or CSCI*150/L, and CSCI*210, and MATH*174) An introduction to the fundamental aspects of a computer system's structure and behavior; binary arithmetic, combinational logic, circuit design, instruction sets, register operations and flip-flops, control system functions, memories, interrupt structures, processors, and performance measures will be covered. S
CSCI*310.Title: Intro to Computer Architecture

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Students must have complete CSCI*211, CSCI*216, and MATH*174 with a grade of C or better.
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

CSCI*311.Description: (3 credits)(Prereq: A grade of 'C' or better in CSCI*211, CSCI*216, and MATH*174) Introduction to the high-level architecture of computer systems and the hardware-software interface. major design features of hardware components are discussed. Topics include instruction set architectures, processor designs, memory components, power, storage devices, device drivers, kernels, bootloaders, firmware, and partition tables. F,S
CSCI*311.Title: System Architecture

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Students must have completed CSCI*216 with a grade of C or  better
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

CSCI*316.Description: (3 credits)(Prereq: a grade of C or better in CSCI*216) A continuation of Linux Fundamentals I. Topics covered include file systems, disk partitioning, accessing network storage, SELinux, schedule tasks, firewalls, and troubleshooting. F,S
CSCI*316.Title: Linux Fundamentals II

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Student must have received a grade of 'C' or better in CSCI*204, CSCI*207, CSCI*208, CSCI*209, or CSCI*220.
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

CSCI*330.Description: (3 credits)(Prereq: A grade of 'C' or better in CSCI*204, CSCI*220, CSCI*207, CSCI*208, or CSCI*209) An introduction to modern systems analysis and software engineering practices. Major topics include software development methodologies, the software development cycle, and software architectures. F,S
CSCI*330.Title: System Analysis/Software Engin

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Take 12 hours of CSCI courses numbered 120 or above with a minumum grade of C
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

CSCI*335.Description: (3 credits)(Prereq: 12 hours of CSCI courses numbered 120 or above, all with a grade of C or better) This course will cover techniques in project management based on the Project Management Body of Knowledge from the Project Management Institute. F,S.
CSCI*335.Title: Project Management

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Students must have received a grade of 'C' or better in CSCI*145 or CSCI*150/L.
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

CSCI*343.Description: (3 credits)(Prereq: A grade of 'C' or better in CSCI*145 or CSCI*150/L) Course presents a thorough introduction to the design and development of applciations for mobile devices. Topics include Navigation, Notifications, Graphics, User Interface Design, User Interface Development, Storage, Messaging, and Testing. Offered as needed
CSCI*343.Title: Intro Mobile App Development

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Student must have completed CSCI*204, CSCI*220, CSCI*207, CSCI*208, or CSCI*209 with grade of C or better.
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

CSCI*350.Description: (3 credits)(Prereq: A grade of 'C' or better in CSCI*204, CSCI*220, CSCI*207, CSCI*208, or CSCI*209) Exploration of programming languages, programming paradigms, and advanced programming language concepts. F
CSCI*350.Title: Organization of Prog Languages

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Student must have completed CSCI 220 with a grade of C or above.
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

CSCI*356.Description: (3 credits)(Prereq: A grade of 'C' or better in CSCI*220) Basic concepts and terminology of operating systems, I/0 and interrupt structures, system structures, processor scheduling, processes and process synchronization, deadlocks, memory management, and other concepts. F
CSCI*356.Title: Operating Systems

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Student must have taken CSCI 120 with grade of C or better
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

CSCI*375.Description: (3 credits)(Prereq: CSCI 120 with a grade of C or better) Concepts of multimedia applications are introduced with a focus on multimedia representation, processing, storage, and implementation. Topic areas include audio, image, video, animation, compression technologies, and standards. Tools and techniques for appropriate design and implementation of multimedia applications will be explored. F.
CSCI*375.Title: Intro to Multimedia Apps

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Student must have completed CSCI 220 and MATH 160, or MATH*160B, with a minimum grade of C.
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

CSCI*380.Description: (3 credits)(Prereq: A grade of 'C' or better in CSCI*220 and MATH*160 or MATH*160B) An introductory course in the analysis of algorithms, with emphasis on computational complexity including practical applications and the analysis of specific problems and algorithms; course investigates most commonly used algorithms design techniques and also introduces the notion of "hard" problems and approximate solutions. F.
CSCI*380.Title: Intro Analysis of Algorithms

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Student must have completed CSCI*270 minumum grade of C.
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

CSCI*385.Description: (3 credits)(Prereq: A grade of 'C' or better in CSCI*270) Comprehensive survey of security policies, models and mechanisms for confidentiality, integrity, management and legal and ethical issues. F,S
CSCI*385.Title: Intro Info Systems Security

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Take CSCI*385; Minimum grade C;
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

CSCI*386.Description: (3 credits)(Prereq: A grade of "C" or better in CSCI 385) Covers offensive security topics including: ethical hacking, penetration testing, threats and vulnerabilities, security tools, and the phases of an attack. F.
CSCI*386.Title: Offensive Security

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Student must have completed CSCI 220 with a grade of C or above.
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

CSCI*390.Description: (3 credits)(Prereq: A grade of 'C' or better in CSCI*220) General models of computation, formal languages and automa theory and algorithmic unsolvability. S
CSCI*390.Title: Theory of Computation

CSCI*399.Description: (1-3 credits)(Prereq: Consent of instructor and approved contract) Directed study and/or research on specific topics.
CSCI*399.Title: Independent Study

CSCI*400.Description: (0)(Prereq: Senior status and permission of the instructor) This course provides various resources to graduating seniors including strategies for job searching and/or entry to graduate school. Students will complete all final assessments required to maintain currency and quality of the program. It is intended for majors to take in their last semester prior to graduation. Pass/Fail grading only. Grading is S or U.
CSCI*400.Title: Senior Assessment

CSCI*401.Description: (3 credits)(Prereq: CSCI major with senior level status or permission of the instructor) This course examines ethical and professional issues in the computing disciplines. Topics include the ACM Code of Ethics, general moral responsibilities, privacy, security, intellectual property, career preparation, job search strategies, and methods of evaluating salary and benefit offers. Students complete all necessary curriculum assessments required to maintain the currency and quality of academic programs offered by the Department of Computing Sciences. F,S
CSCI*401.Title: Ethics & Professional Issues

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Student must have completed CSCI 225 and CSCI 303 with a minimum grade of C.
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

CSCI*409.Description: (3)(Prereq: CSCI 225 and CSCI 303 with a grade of C or better) Advanced topics in the development and deployment of web-based applications. Topics include advanced middleware programming concepts and development of dynamic websites. Students will write a full-scale web application as their final project. S.
CSCI*409.Title: Advanced Web App Development

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Student must have taken CSCI 211 with a grade of C or better.
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

CSCI*415.Description: (3 credits)(Prereq: A grade of 'C' or better in CSCI*211) Topics in systems administration include application server management, deployment of websites, domain name service, web services, security, backup and recovery, and e-mail management. F,S
CSCI*415.Title: Windows System Administration

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Students must have completed CSCI 316 with a minimum grade of C or better.
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

CSCI*416.Description: (3 credits)(Prereq: A grade of 'C' or better in CSCI*316) This course provides an introduction to Linux system administration, including open-source software applications. Topics include managing software installations, configuring hardware drivers, implementing authentication and authorization systems, automating management tasks, and configuring services. Students gain hands-on experience managing Linux systems. F,S
CSCI*416.Title: Linux System Administration

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Student must have completed CSCI 225 with a minimum grade of C.
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

CSCI*425.Description: (Prereq: Grade of C or better in CSCI 225) An exploration of advanced database topics will be covered. Topics may include the efficiency of advanced queries, indexing structures, database and SQL optimizations, backup and recovery, NoSQL ang big data concepts. F
CSCI*425.Title: Database Systems Design

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Students must have completed CSCI*270 and CSCI*316 with a grade of 'C' or better.
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

CSCI*427.Description: (3 credits)(Prereq: A grade of 'C' or better in CSCI 270 and CSCI*316) Introduction to, and practice of, designing and integrating, large-scale information processing systems, with a focus on selecting and implementing hardware and softwre systems to develop an appropriate IT solution. Topics include systems provisioning, software integration, hardware management, availability, scalability, and disaster recovery capability. Students will design an integrated information system to implement a solution to a case study problem. S
CSCI*427.Title: Systems Integration

CSCI*434.Description: (3 credits)(Prereq: Students must be enrolled in at least 60 hours prior to registration) This course introduces students to the collection, preservation, presentation and preparation of computer-based evidence for the purposes of criminal law enforcement or civil litigation. These activities define the central roles of computer forensic practitioners involved in investigating computer crime scenes and torts involving computers. Students prepare to assist in the formulation and implementation of organizational computer forensics preparedness policies, to determine the necessity for future procedures, extend governance processes to allow for proper future forensic investigations, and to be contributing members of computer forensic investigation teams. F
CSCI*434.Title: Digital Forensics

CSCI*435.Description: (3 credits)(Prereq: Junior standing) This course complements CSCI*434 - Digital Forensics by focusing on techniques to reduce the amount of information collected and stored by computer systems, with an emphasis on protecting the system and user from fraud and identity theft resulting from a compromised or stolen system. Concepts related to privacy in the digital world are discussed. Vulnerabilities in digital devices are explored in the context of a dystopian society in which citizens are under perpetual surveillance. S
CSCI*435.Title: Anti Forensics/Digital Privacy

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Student must have completed CSCI 220.
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

CSCI*440.Description: (3)(Prereq: a grade of C or better in CSCI 220) An  overview of the elements of 2D and 3D graphics,  includes topics on raster graphics, geometrical  transformations, parallel and perspective  projections for 3D viewing, interaction  techniques, representation of curves and  surfaces, solid modeling and topics on visual  realism. F or S
CSCI*440.Title: Intro to Computer Graphics

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Take 12 hours of CSCI courses numbered 120 or above with a minimum grade of C.
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

CSCI*444.Description: (3)(Prereq: 12 hours of CSCI courses numbered 120 or above, all with a grade C or better) A large percentage of the world's software is devoted to the interface between computers and their users, and usability is one of the key factors deciding whether a software project succeeds or fails. This course explores the requirements analysis, design and evaluation of the User Interface in the context of Software Engineering Processes. Specific methods and design problems will be illustrated with real world examples in information technology, the internet, communications, mobility, multimedia and speech technologies. F.
CSCI*444.Title: Human Computer Interaction

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Students must have taken CSCI*145 or CSCI*150/L and MATH*160 or MATH*160B, or MATH*242/L with a grade of 'C' or better.
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

CSCI*445.Description: (3 credits)(Prereq: A grade of 'C' or better in CSCI*145 or CSCI*150/L, and MATH*160 or MATH*160B, or MATH*242/L) This course introduces the theoretical foundations and methodologies of digital image processing and analysis. Topics include intensity transformations, contrast enhancement, filtering in the spatial and frequency domains, restoration and reconstruction, edge detection, feature extraction, morphological operations, image segmentation, object recognition, and color image processing. F or S, as needed
CSCI*445.Title: Image Processing and Analysis

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Students must have completed 12 credit hours of CSCI courses 120 or above, all with a grade of C or better.
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

CSCI*455.Description: (3 credits)(Prereq: 12 credit hours of CSCI courses 120 or above, all with a grade of C or better) This course deals with the data science and analytics for information systems and technology applications. This course also introduces data management process for data science and analytics. How the data relate and aggregate in analytic databases and how they are used by analytical tools will be explored through case studies and projects. Offered as needed
CSCI*455.Title: Data Science & Analytics

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Student must have completed CSCI*210, CSCI*220, CSCI*270, CSCI*330, CSCI*356 and MATH*160 or MATH*160B all with a minimum grade of C or better.
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

CSCI*473.Description: (3 credits)(Prereq: a grade of 'C' or better in CSCI*210, CSCI*220, CSCI*270, CSCI*330, CSCI*356, and MATH*160 or MATH*160B) This course introduces parallel computer architectures and their programming. It includes an introduction to MPI and OpenMP and a number of engineering problems, including numerical simulations. It also provides an introduction to performance evaluation and modeling as well as scalability analysis. F,S
CSCI*473.Title: Intro to Parallel Systems

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Students must have taken CSCI 225 and CSCI 330 with a grade of C or better.
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

CSCI*475.Description: (Prereq: CSCI 225 or CSCI 330 with a grade of C or better) A study of decision support systems. Topics include computerized decision support and business intelligence systems, modeling, and methodologies. Course will cover data and web mining concepts, knowledge management technologies, collaboration techniques, and intelligent systems. Offered as needed. S
CSCI*475.Title: Decision Support Systems

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Student must have completed CSCI 220 with a grade of 'C' or better.
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

CSCI*480.Description: (3 credits)(Prereq: A grade of 'C' or better in CSCI*220) Covers the fundamentals of Artificial Intelligence (AI); topics and techniques for analyzing and developing intelligent systems; programming in an AI language. Coverage may include applications in areas such as expert systems, neural networks, fuzzy logic, robotics, etc. F or S, as needed
CSCI*480.Title: Intro Artificial Intelligence

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Students must have completed CSCI 220 and MATH 160, or MATH 160B, or MATH 242/L all with a minimum grade of C.
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

CSCI*484.Description: (3 credits)(Prereq: A grade of 'C' or better in CSCI 220 and MATH 160, or MATH 160B, or MATH 242/L) This course provides an introduction to pattern recognition and machine learning. Topics may include probabilistic learning, linear discriminants, neural networks, unsupervised learning, decision trees, Bayesian networks, support vector machines, and reinforcement learning. F or S, as needed
CSCI*484.Title: Machine Learning

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Student must have completed CSCI 220 with a grade of 'C' or better.
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

CSCI*485.Description: (3 credits)(Prereq: A grade of 'C' or better in CSCI*220) An introduction to the fundamentals of mobile robotics including robot hardware, sensors, obstacle avoidance, navigation, mapping, path planning and robot architectures. F or S, as needed
CSCI*485.Title: Introduction to Robotics

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Student must have completed CSCI 330 with a grade of C or above.
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

CSCI*490.Description: (Prereq: CSCI 330 with a grade of C or better) This course is a continuation of the software engineering design principles introduced in Computer Science 330. Topics include project requirements, design specification, testing, project management and group dynamics. Students will design, code, test, and implement an information system as part of a team project. F
CSCI*490.Title: Software Engineering II

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Student must have completed CSCI 330 and CSCI 225 with a minimum grade of C.
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

CSCI*495.Description: (3 credits)(Prereq: A grade of 'C' or better in CSCI*225 and CSCI*330) This senior capstone course integrates and synthesizes the material covered in the field of Information SYstems, including Systems Analysis, Project Management, System Development and Deployment, and Security. Students develop a practical solution to an information systems problem. Presentation is both oral and written. Lecture topics may vary from semester to semester. F or S, as needed.
CSCI*495.Title: Information Systems Capstone

CourseRequisites.DisplayText: Students must be Junior standing or higher, minimum overall GPA of 2.5, and one of the following courses with a grade of C or better: CSCI 220, CSCI 330, CSCI 415, CSCI 416.
CourseRequisites.DisplayTextExtension: - Must be completed prior to taking this course.

CSCI*497.Description: (1-3)(Prereq: Junior standing or higher, minimum overall GPA of 2.5, and one of the following courses with a grade of C or better: CSCI*220, CSCI*330, CSCI*415, or CSCI*416) Supervised work experience of at least 150 hours. Program format is approved by the area director. A written final paper is required. F,S,Su.
CSCI*497.Title: Computer Science Internship

CSCI*499.Description: Special projects and recent developments in Computer Science  selected to meet current faculty and student interest.
CSCI*499.Title: Topics in Computer Science
